Open White Spruce (*Picea glauca*) forest surrounding a small Black Spruce (*Picea mariana*) bog. Understory vegetation dominated by feathermosses (*Ptilium* sp.) and Labrador Tea (*Rhododendron groenlandicum*).

recordings.rmk: Fol xc269778.  Same bird. Possible Swainson's Warbler? (not listed but rarely gives brief song in fall) after 1 min, 45. Phone is five two-noted phrases after that.  Photos clearly showing identity of the bird in this recording were obtained.

recordings.loc: Red River National Wildlife Refuge- Headquarters Unit, Bossier Parish, Louisiana
recordings.rmk: Fall migrant giving distinct snappy and quite Acadian Flycatcher-like "psiw" calls in response to brief playback of "jid-lek" song after suspecting id.  Probably two present. Bird observed flycatching/ frequent sallies under low canopy. Numerous photos taken by Ronnie Maum- with several clearly showing identity of the bird. Bird often close, within ~25' of us. Acadian Flycatcher and unseen Alder Flycatcher also here, among others. North end of pecan orchard. Area of thick pecan and roughleaf dogwood/other saplings somewhat covered with wild grape.

recordings.loc: Escanaba, Delta County, Michigan
recordings.rmk: Unmodified recording. Distant bird heard making plaintive Pwee calls shorter than those of an Eastern Wood Pewee. Recording showed not only these Pwee calls but also Pseep calls. Quality is not good because the bird was distant and I was recording past Cottonwood Trees with moving leaves and through conifers, but Pwee calls improve at 3:00. About 2 seconds between the Pseep calls and a variable amount of time between the Pwee calls. Pseep calls are all at the beginning of the recording, although the bird had been calling the Pwee calls before I turned on the recorder.

Park is a developed island with parking lots, beach areas, campgrounds and cottages. There are large lawn areas with ornamental trees and shrubs.  Flycatcher was initially making *puwee* call and switched to the shorter  *pyu* call prior to the start of recording.

Recorded with smartphone (Moto G).

recordings.loc: Reserva de Vida Silvestre El Armado, Olancho
Moose Lake, Mendenhall Valley, Juneau, Alaska
recordings.rmk:
The only modification to the recording was that the beginning and ends were clipped off to shorten recording.

Playback was used once but not again and bird was very vocal; on using the che bek or che bunk "song."

Habitat:  Alder and cottonwood; bird mid story.

Behavior:  Bird seemingly passing through area, vocal and on the move; did not stick around long.

Plumage:  adult breeding; distinct yellow wash on breast and throat, distinct eye ring with extension in front and behind eye, prominent whitish wing bars.

Weather: partly sunny and mild; somewhat buggy; nice morning for Juneau.

recordings.loc: Cold Lake, Alberta
recordings.rmk: Bird seen well by four experienced birders, and high quality photos taken (but not mine!). Black spruce bog with no least flycatchers in the area. https://ebird.org/view/checklist/S18736735

recordings.loc: Westborough, Worcester, Massachusetts
recordings.rmk: Recording amplified by 5.  Originally I'd paused to record the Alder Flycatcher, since it was close.  As I turned the recorder on, I heard the 'perwee' sound that I've attributed to the Yellow-bellied Flycatcher.  The sound doesn't fit exactly, but seems to be the best match.  The bird in question calls at 0:00.3, 0:04.0, 0:08.0, 0:15.9, and at 0:27.6 seconds.  Bird was not seen.  Note a Least Flycatcher was singing for a few min before and after this recording.  This recording was from the dense understory adjacent to a swampy wooded wetland.  There were alder trees present.  All birds were well back and tucked in the understory.

recordings.loc: Ecoparque El Espino, Santa Tecla, La Libertad
Wekiwa Springs State Park, Apopka, Orange, Florida
recordings.rmk: This bird was recorded from a boat along the Wekiva River on March 1, 2013. The habitat is extensive hardwood floodplain swamp. It called repeatedly for quite some time but never showed itself. The call notes sound like a reasonably good fit to the "turee" type call of YBFL to me. However, this species is quite rare in Florida, especially in winter/spring. I'd appreciate thoughts on this one. I recorded this with my iphone 4s and amplified it slightly using Audacity. It is otherwise unedited. You have to forgive the background noise. Someone was digging through a pelican case on the aluminum boat hull and created a lot of noise. Here I isolated one call note from this recording: http://xeno-canto.org/150001

recordings.loc: Wekiwa Springs State Park, Apopka, Orange, Florida
recordings.rmk: This bird was recorded from a boat along the Wekiva River on March 1, 2013. The habitat is extensive hardwood floodplain swamp. It called repeatedly for quite some time but never showed itself. The call notes sound like a reasonably good fit to the "turee" type call of YBFL to me. However, this species is quite rare in Florida, especially in winter/spring. I'd appreciate thoughts on this one. I recorded this with my iphone 4s and amplified it slightly using Audacity. It is otherwise unedited. You have to forgive the background noise. Someone was digging through a pelican case on the aluminum boat hull and created a lot of noise. I isolated one call note and cleaned it up a bit. I'll upload that recording momentarily.

recordings.loc: Algonquin Highlands, Haliburton County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: Sings 'pu-weee' call 3 times in recording. Think this is likely Yellow-bellied flycatcher. Mainly because of spruce bog habitat but also because it seems slightly less musical then Eastern Pewee. Both species could be present in the area as this bog is adjacent to mature deciduous forest. Singing from spruce/tamarack low area adjacent to Livingstone Lake Rd and creek.
